I am late to the show i see - already 5 tabs gee...

Any way.. When I bought KSP2 and joined the forum to bug report I was blown away by seeing a 2010 style forum, healthy and thriving.. it makes me a bit sad that feels like its been dying together with KSP2.. i really liked it here. 

But maybe its only KSP 2 segment that is dying.. is the KSP1 segment alive? Ive been considering getting KSP1... but I just really dont like the HUD and I prefered the KSP2 looks of the Kerbals.. any way im going off a tangent.

All i wanted to say was that i really liked the KSP community and i would be sad to see it go.
It'll be a shame if the forum goes down. What's the ballpark annual cost to maintain a forum of this size (whatever the number of views/contributions is)?

48 minutes ago, tater said:

It'll be a shame if the forum goes down. What's the ballpark annual cost to maintain a forum of this size (whatever the number of views/contributions is)?

I don't think it's that much. I'm a member on multiple other forums that are owned/maintained by private individuals that have membership/post counts on the same order of magnitude as this one. But those forums use advertising/merchandising to help offset their expenses. So, don't gripe if it comes to that, folks.
If the worst does come to fruition, I'm glad I got to enjoy it before the end. Thanks to everyone who built this forum to what it is today.

A forum was the best (only?) way for the modding community to thrive. Imagine if you had 4 favorite mods, and one was discussed on the Steam forums, another Discord, Reddit, and Twitter. It would stifle discussion of mod interoperability and limit discovery of new mods.

Some mods that used to be discussed here are now on Discord or Patreon

I think everyone is wrong. When T2 needs a forum, it will reuse the IP and physical space of the Kerbal. 
And be thankful that it has not yet acted as it should by law, since they are the owners of the KERBAL seal and can ask for royalties for the accounts opened on PATREON or Youtube for brand use. 

Faced with this reality, they should give thanks to IG's effort to squander the franchise and allow it to soon become a real headache for many in the face of the demands of lawyers.

I sent a message via Take2's contact form! And I hope that someone will read it and pass it on to those responsible!

Even if it doesn't help, I hope that it can have some effect...

Here is the message I sent to Take2!
 

Quote

Since you closed the company Private Division, which was responsible for the game Kerbal Space Program 2, the community and all players of this game are in great excitement!

This game was and still is in Early Access....
There are still numerous updates that were promised and what the players are waiting for!

For the price you pay for the game, it is not insignificant.

So what are your plans for the game and do you want to keep the players and the community in the dark?

Check out the forum and the Discord of this game and you will see that this game is worth continuing!

I am a player of this game myself and I enjoy playing it, as do many others!

And if the development of this game continues, more people would buy this game!

Don't give up on this game! And let the main developers continue to work on it!

Sincerely
One of the fans of KSP2!

I would pay for access to these forums to be maintained. Can we set up a patreon or something for the moderation team and server space? I support several ksp modders on patreon, and spacedock, it would only make sense to also support the forums in the same way.
The KSP Community will endure with the same spirit that all spacefarers do.

On 7/9/2024 at 12:27 AM, PDCWolf said:

These two statements are in contradiction. The mature answer is not to start hurling insults around and taking it out on the easiest, biggest target. Sinking KSP2 took a lot of people, a lot of missed calls, and a lot bad stuff from multiple sides. And no, this isn't defending TakeTwo, but actually pointing out that they aren't the only ones to blame, they're just the easy target by being a faceless corporation that's not gonna come swinging back at you. The answer also isn't blaming the people that got scammed for wanting to play another fun game. That kind of outrage-tivism died long ago on the worst times of Twitter witch-hunting.

It has come to light that a lot of the early work on ksp2 was under tight restrictions set by take two that lead to the trouble dev history. You can point the finger and the mistakes made by Star Theory or Intercept Games all you want but at the end of the day the root of all of this stems from Take Two
